comments.content:
Nice email address, Christopher. :-)

I suggest you change the “@” in your comment to “[at]” to avoid spambots (i.e., “typographer [at] gmail dot com”).

i always wondered about that advice.

are the e-mail address-harvesters  
so stupid as to not figure out that  
“dot com” stands for “.com” and  
the “at” that comes earlier is a  
stand-in for an “@”-sign?

especially when the “dot com” is  
preceded by something like “gmail”,  
or something similarly obvious?

i mean, if it was some government  
programmer, sure, that would be  
good enough to fool them, but  
these spammers seem crafty...

so i think it’s just superstitious.

-bowerbird
You don’t think removing the ’h’ was circumvention enough? ;-)

Lived in Antigonish, Nova Scotia for a few months.

Before that, “Halifax” was, to my awareness, a quaint substitute term for “Hell” in black-and-white 1950s movies. As in, “Oh, goodness, Mary Jane! Sometimes I just wish Chet would just go to Halifax!”

But the actual experience was pretty much just like that Annie Proulx novel, The Shipping News. Cold, windy, harsh, barren and beautiful.

Like I like my women and my glyphs.

(Just kiddin’!) Wondering out loud — what typefaces have come out of that region? What the Halifax would they look like?

Ray Fenwick is from Halifax. And while I’ve never seen him around typophile, he certainly could qualify:

[http://www.coandco.ca/ray/](http://web.archive.org/web/20090426181934/http:/www.coandco.ca/ray/ "http://www.coandco.ca/ray/")
